headline.seo: Mexico Puts Its Children on a Diet
headline.print_headline: Potato Chips at Recess? Try Prickly Pear Instead
headline.main: Mexico Puts Its Children on a Diet

docs.lead_paragraph: A new set of rules regulating what schoolchildren can and cannot eat is considered a first step in battling obesity in one of the fattest countries in the world.
docs.snippet: A new set of rules regulating what schoolchildren can and cannot eat is considered a first step in battling obesity in one of the fattest countries in the world.

headline.main: Roast, as Usual, on the Gridiron Menu

docs.abstract: President Obama indulges the press, and himself, with an appearance at the annual Gridiron Club dinner.
docs.lead_paragraph: Whether it was worth the wait is beside the point: In the third year of his term, President Obama on Saturday finally attended the annual dinner-and-spoofs gala of the 126-year-old Gridiron Club, made up of Washington's journalistic elite, and won the night with his roast of Republicans, Democrats, the media and - what was most appreciated -- himself.
docs.snippet: President Obama indulges the press, and himself, with an appearance at the annual Gridiron Club dinner.

docs.lead_paragraph: Reducing childhood obesity should be an all-hands-on-deck issue, including the hands of the government.
docs.snippet: Reducing childhood obesity should be an all-hands-on-deck issue, including the hands of the government.

headline.seo: Breast-Feeding Boutique Battles a Condo Board
headline.print_headline: Breast-Feeding Boutique Feuds With a Condo Board
headline.main: Breast-Feeding Boutique in Feud With Condo Board

docs.lead_paragraph: A Manhattan business that caters to lactating women is battling the board of the landmark building it calls home.
docs.snippet: A Manhattan business that caters to lactating women is battling the board of the landmark building it calls home.

docs.abstract: A new "peace movement" seeks to halt "the collateral damage" of the failed war on obesity.
docs.lead_paragraph: The start of Lent today will offer many of us yet another opportunity to renew that resolution we made at the start of the year (and abandoned by the time February rolled in), to lose the extra poundage. But before you vow to give up your glasses of Cabernet and your plates of pasta primavera, you might want to consider H.A.E.S., or Health at Every Size, a new "peace movement" that one of its proponents, Linda Bacon, a nutritionist in the Department of Nutrition at the University of California, Davis, says was designed to halt "the collateral damage" - food and body preoccupation, self-hatred and eating disorders - that has resulted from the failed war on obesity. H.A.E.S. is based on the idea that "the best way to improve health is to honor your body," and it supports the adoption of good health habits simply for the sake of health and well-being rather than weight control.Bacon and Lucy Aphramor, a National Health Service specialist dietitian and an honorary research fellow at the Applied Research Center in Health and Lifestyle Interventions at Coventry University in England, published a paper in Nutrition Journal earlier this year. It argues that a weight-focused approach geared toward losing weight is - surprise! - not especially effective in either reducing the weight or creating healthier bodies. In fact, they say, such an approach can unintentionally lead to weight gain and worse health.
docs.snippet: A new "peace movement" seeks to halt "the collateral damage" of the failed war on obesity.

headline.seo: Drawing Out Meals Doesn’t Curb Snacking, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Leisurely Meals Don’t Curb Snacking, Study Finds
headline.main: Leisurely Meals Don’t Curb Snacking, Study Finds

docs.lead_paragraph: Dutch researchers set out to see whether the speed of consumption had an effect on diners’ feelings of satiety and on the chemical signals, or hormones, involved in appetite regulation.
docs.snippet: Dutch researchers set out to see whether the speed of consumption had an effect on diners’ feelings of satiety and on the chemical signals, or hormones, involved in appetite regulation.
